title: First letters: அ, ஆ, ம, ப, ட
pages:
Welcome! Let's learn Tamil!

Tamil (actual pronunciation Thamil, also romanized as Thamizh) is a classical ancient languaage!

There are 247 letters in the Tamil alphabet, and while this may seem daunting at first, it follows a pattern that gets easier to follow as we go along.

There are only 30 basic letters - 12 vowels and 18 consonants.

Rest of the alphabet is derived from these 30 basic letters with few patterns.

Hence Tamil is one of the easiest languages to learn.
In the first lesson, we will learn 2 vowels and 3 consonants.
The first vowel of the tamil alphabet is அ, pronounced like the A in 'allow'. Practice tracing it below.
Whenever I introduce a new letter, remember to pronounce it out of your mouth so you get used to it. It's really important to practice these sounds if you want to learn efficiently!
The second vowel is simply the long version of அ, which is written as ஆ. Simply pronounce it longer as அ!
The first consanant we will learn is ம், pronounced like the English letter M.

Next we will see how consonants are combined with vowels.
With the vowels we have learned so far - அ (a) & ஆ (aa),
There are three ways this consonant ம் shows up:
ம் (m), ம (ma), and மா (maa)
ம்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ம்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ம: When it is written without a dot, it defaults to the அ vowel, resulting in the 'ma' sound. ம் + அ = ம

ம்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ம: When it is written without a dot, it defaults to the அ vowel, resulting in the 'ma' sound. ம் + அ = ம

மா: When "ா" is present after a consonant, it is the ஆ vowel, resulting in the 'maa' sound.
ம் + ஆ = மா

The next consonant is the ப், pronounced like the English letter P. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Writing_Tamil_22.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
Now let's look at combining ப் with vowels. The same rules that apply to ம் (m), ம (ma), மா (maa), also apply to ப் (p), ப (pa), பா (paa).
ப்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ப்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ப் combined with அ makes ப (pa). ப் + அ = ப

ப்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ப் combined with அ makes ப (pa). ப் + அ = ப

ப் combined with ஆ makes பா (paa). ப் + ஆ = பா

The next consonant we learn is the ட், pronounced like the English letter T. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Writing_Tamil_18.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
Now let's look at combining ட் with vowels. The same pattern we saw with ம் (m), ம (ma), மா (maa) and ப் (p), ப (pa), பா (paa) continue here.
ட்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ட்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ட் combined with அ makes ட (ta). ட் + அ = ட

ட்: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

ட் combined with அ makes ட (ta). ட் + அ = ட

ட் combined with ஆ makes டா (taa). ட் + ஆ = டா

Note: In Tamil, hard consonant sounds like ப and ட (and few others you will learn in subsequent lessons) will be pronounced differently based on the context. For example,

ப can represent the sound of pa or ba.
ட can represent the sound of ta or da.

You will learn this better as you get familiar with more words
Now, let's put what you've learned to practice!

title: Adding 3 consonants: ச, க, த
pages: Introducing three letters this lesson just to keep it simple and expand on the usage of the அ and ஆ vowels.

க்: pronounced somewhere between English K and G. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Writing_Tamil_14.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
க் combined with அ makes க (ka). க் + அ = க Depending upon the context, it can represent ka, ga or ha sounds.
க் combined with ஆ makes கா (kaa). க் + ஆ = கா

த்: pronounced like 'th' in English. It's the 'th' used in Tamil! <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e4/Writing_Tamil_20.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
த் combined with அ makes த (tha). த் + அ = த. Depending upon the context, it can sound tha or dha.
த் combined with ஆ makes தா (thaa). த் + ஆ = தா

ச்: pronounced like 'ch' in English. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Writing_Tamil_16.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
ச் combined with அ makes ச (cha). ச் + அ = ச Depending upon the context, it can represent cha or sa sounds.
ச் combined with ஆ makes சா (chaa). ச் + ஆ = சா

title: Knee! இ, ன, ண, ந
pages: This level might be a little tricky for new learners who have no experience whatsoever. I'll try and take it slow!
We will learn a new vowel and 3 consonants in this lesson.
Let's get into the consonants first: ன, ண, ந. They all sound like the same English letter: N.

Why on earth would Tamilians make three different letters for the same sound? Well, as we continue learning the language, it's just one of those rules that become more common and that we have to deal with.
So, lets compare the two that look similar, ன and ண. These two actually have a slightly different pronounciation that can be hard to miss!

<canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/31/Writing_Tamil_31.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

<canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6c/Writing_Tamil_19.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

Notice where your tongue goes when you pronounce 'n'. The difference between the two looped (ன) and three looped (ண) is where you place your tongue. For the two looped you place it next to your teeth, and the three looped is placed farther back on the roof of your mouth.

Tongue placement is important when pronouncing certain consonants in Tamil. I will expand on this in later lessons, but it's important to know that there are two different types of 'n'. I will admit, however, when you hear it there seems to be no difference, and are easy to mix up!

The last 'n', ந, is pronounced like the two looped 'n' (ன) but is only used in the beginning of words and right before த. ன and ண NEVER come in the beginning of a word! <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/Writing_Tamil_21.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
Pay attention to correct pronunciation, and notice where the different Ns are while learning these new words!

Now, let's introduce the new vowel: இ, pronounced like the i in 'bin'. Practice drawing this vowel, it might be a little tricky at first! <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/87/Tamil_writing_4.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
To combine இ with consonants, you add an arc from on top to the bottom right of a consonant. பி (pi), மி (mi), தி (thi), கி(ki) , டி(di)
Now let's review what you learned!

title: Ear! ஈ, ர, ற
pages: In this lesson, we will learn a new vowel and 2 consonants.

New vowel: ஈ, the longer version of இ. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Writing_Tamil_5.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
To combine it with consonants, you add a loop at the top at the same place where இ's line was.
The next two consanants are both a version of R. Same as the last lesson, these two vary in their pronounciation depending on where you place your tongue.

ர is the 'softer version', ற is the 'harder version', which just means you place your tongue farther in. (when ர் is written, the bottom line is often ommited as it's not really needed. it's still a good practice to write it though) <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/18/Writing_Tamil_%2814.12%29.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

It's important that ற has another way to being pronounced, when it's placed like so: ற்ற. This makes the ற் be pronounced like a t, so it makes a 'tr' sound. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e3/Writing_Tamil_30.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
While this next set of words doesn't have a double ற, there will be some in the future, so watch out for those!
With the introduction of ர and ற, we can also expand on the ன, ண, and ந rules from before.
ன is called றன்னகரம் as it is used when paired with ற (as ன்ற).
ண is called டண்ணகரம் for the same reason (as ண்ட)
And remember, only ந goes in the beginning of (real) words, and is called தந்நகரம் because it shows up in the middle of words as ந்த.
As you recognize more and more words, the pattern becomes more evident and easier to tell which one to use when hearing a new word.

title: Aisle! ஐ, ள, ல, ழ
pages: In this lesson, we will learn a new vowel and 3 consonants.

New vowel: ஐ, pronounced ai. <canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/75/Writing_Tamil_10.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

To combine ஐ with consonants, you add
ை
character before the consonant.

பை (pai), மை (mai), டை (tai), கை (kai), தை (thai), சை (chai), நை (nai), ணை(nai), னை(nai), ரை(rai), றை(rai)

The new consonants we are going to learn in this lesson represent L sound.
Similar to ன, ண, ந and ர, ற, the L sounds have three variations in Tamil: ல, ள, ழ

It is important to learn the right pronunciation of these different sounds. If you use the wrong version, the meaning of some words could be entirely different. Pronunciation is important so that you can write words out correctly.
Pronunciation in these consonants is dependent on tongue placement. Practice putting your tongue in these different places and pronouncing these consonants.
ல is pronounced at the front of the mouth, at the tip of your front teeth.

ழ is pronounced by flipping the tongue all the way to the back. The ழ sound originated in Tamil, and as it is pronounced so differently, it's mostly romanized as zha. In this course we're romanizing all three as the same, but you still need to pronounce them differently!

ள is pronounced in the middle of these two. A way to differentiating between ள் and ழ் is the two palates of the roof of the mouth: the rough palate is where ள் is pronounced and the soft palate is where ழ் is pronounced. Run your tongue between these palates to feel the difference.

title: aay! எ, ஏ, ய, வ
pages:
In this lesson we will learn two new vowels and two new consonants.
Let's first look at the vowels
எ pronounced like E in 'enter' (a bit longer)
ஏ (pronounced like ae) is longer version of எ.
Open/widen up your mouth when pronouncing these vowels in Tamil.

To combine எ with consonants, you add ெ character before the consonant.
For example பெ (pe), மெ (me), டெ (te), கெ (ke), தெ (the), செ (che), நெ (ne), ணெ (ne), னெ (ne), ரெ (re), றெ (re), லெ (le), ளெ (le), ழெ (le)

To combine ஏ with consonants, you add ே character before the consonant.
For example பே (pae), மே (mae), டே (tae), கே (kae), தே (thae), சே (chae), நே (nae), ணே (nae), னே (nae), ரே (rae), றே (rae), லே (lae), ளே (lae), ழே (lae)
The new consonants we are going to learn in this lesson are ய்  (represent the consonant form of y) and வ் (represent v sound).

<canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d4/Writing_Tamil_24.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

<canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Writing_Tamil_27.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>

Now let's see how these new consonants ய் and வ் will appear with எ and ஏ.
ய் with எ is யெ (ye)
ய் with ஏ is யே (yae)
வ் with எ is வெ (ve)
வ் with ஏ is வே (vae)

title: ow! ஒ, ஓ, ஔ
pages: In this lesson we will learn three new vowels.

New vowels in this lesson are
ஒ pronounced like the first O in 'tomato'
ஓ (pronounced like second O in 'tomato') is longer version of ஒ.
ஔ (pronounced like ou in 'sound' or 'ow!')

To combine ஒ with consonants, you add ெ character before the consonant and ா character after the consonant.
For example பொ (po), மொ (mo), டொ (to), கொ (ko), தொ (tho), சொ (cho), நொ (no), ணொ (no), னொ (no), ரொ (ro), றொ (ro), லொ (lo), ளொ (lo), ழொ (lo)

To combine ஓ with consonants, you add ே character before the consonant and ா character after the consonant.
For example போ (pO), மோ (mO), டோ (tO), கோ (kO), தோ (thO), சோ (chO), நோ (nO), ணோ (nO), னோ (nO), ரோ (rO), றோ (rO), லோ (lO), ளோ (lO), ழோ (lO)

To combine ஔ with consonants, you add ெ character before the consonant and ள character after the consonant.
For example பௌ (pou), மௌ (mou), டௌ (tou), கௌ (kou), தௌ (thou), சௌ (chou), நௌ (nou), ணௌ (nou), னௌ (nou), ரௌ (rou), றௌ(rou), லௌ(lou), ளௌ(lou), ழௌ(lou)
Let's review what we learned in this lesson!

title: ngjnjngjng ங், ஞ்
pages:
In this lesson we will learn two new consonants.

With this lesson, we have learned all the consonants.

We will do a review after the next lesson.

New consonants in this lesson are
ங் pronounced like the n in 'ringing' or 'angle'
ஞ், pronounced like n in 'angel'

title: Woohoo! உ, ஊ
pages:
In this lesson we will learn the final vowels, உ and ஊ.
உ is pronounced like u in 'put'
ஊ (pronounced like oo in 'too') is the longer version of உ

<canvas class='draw' data-url='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Writing_Tamil_6.gif'></canvas> <button onclick='document.querySelector(".draw").getContext("2d").clearRect(0, 0, 1000, 1000)'>clear</button>
Combining உ and ஊ with consonants are much more complex than other vowels, so we saved these for last.
To combine உ with consonants, there are three different modifiers used.

ப், வ், ய், ச் use the vertical line modifier.

ப் + உ = பு
வ் + உ = வு
ய் + உ = யு
ச் + உ = சு

ம், ர், க், ழ், ள், ட் use the squiggly modifier.

ம் + உ = மு
ர் + உ = ரு
க் + உ = கு
ழ் + உ = ழு
ள் + உ = ளு
ட் + உ = டு

ந், ன், ண், த், ற், ல் use the combination modifier.

ந் + உ = நு
ன் + உ = னு
ண் + உ = ணு
த் + உ = து
